content_html:
How Can Caretakers Take Care of Themselves?

Susan L Stewart
Apr 1

Living with someone with a chronic illness(es) does not have to be the end of your happiness.

A caregiver asked me once how he should take care of his wife, who is in chronic pain, while still maintaining his own life. If only there were an easy answer!

I have lived with severe chronic pain and overwhelming fatigue for the last 30 years due to fibromyalgia. The pain is so bad I am forced to take serious narcotics just to be able to function. On an occasional good day, I can actually enjoy life and appreciate all that I am blessed with. These days are few and I make sure I appreciate every hour of every one.

I’m going to make some assumptions for the sake of the discussion.

  • Your wife can’t do the things she used to do or wants to do, and you are tired, emotionally and physically.
  • She is sick and unhappy, and you don’t know if you can do this another day.
  • Every day seems like more of the same because nothing gets better. No matter what you do, which doctor she sees or treatment she tries, you are powerless to make any kind of permanent change.

I asked my husband (my caregiver) your question and this is what he said: “You have to try to not be selfish. You have to change the way you look at your life, your outlook on life, and realize you are a caregiver. You have to come to an understanding that you aren’t going to get to do everything you might want to do but you still need time for yourself and time to do things you enjoy. If it gets to a point where she wants you to stay with her all the time and never leave her, it may be time to share your responsibilities with another family member. At some point you may need some outside help so you can get some relief and time away. And, I never forget my wedding vows, made 45 years ago, to love my wife through sickness and in health.”

I have to say my husband is amazing. I have been at a point of being able to do very little for more than ten years. My husband does the grocery shopping, and laundry; he cooks, cleans and holds my hand when it gets really bad. But keep in mind that he has had a lot of years of practice in this caretaker role. He wasn’t always quite as willing to help. It has taken time for him to understand how I feel and what makes it better or worse. It has taken time for me to learn how to help in my small way and what to say to make sure he knows I appreciate him.
 
It’s difficult to describe what it’s like to live with chronic pain, but I’ll try. Pain messes with your mind, thoughts, behavior and patience. It makes it hard to remember things, to enjoy simple things and to be appreciative. It can eat away at your soul if you let it, and make you jealous and bitter, especially about people who seem to walk through life without a care.
 
I had to make a decision more than 20 years ago that I was not going to take my pain, depression and all the other negative feelings out on my husband. I love him, and because I do, I made a commitment to do everything I can to make this as easy on him as possible. I say, “thank you,” and “I’m sorry for . . .” and “I love you” and “I really appreciate everything you do” a lot. I do whatever I can, even if it’s a small thing like putting my cereal bowl and spoon in the dishwasher. If I see a basket of clean towels, I fold them. It’s the thought that counts.

Working out a new life

So what do you do? How do you create a happy life? There are two of you in this relationship and it’s going to take effort from each of you to improve it.

First of all, it is necessary for the caretaker, and the person he takes care of, to come up with a list of things he really doesn’t want to give up. Let’s assume the caretaker is a man and loves to play golf. So, once a week he needs five hours to play golf. Maybe when it’s too cold for golf, he and his buddies go bowling. Whatever. Just think how good it would be to get away from the pressure, and spend some time on the quiet golf course, get some exercise and breathe some fresh air.

Then he has to decide if his wife can be alone for five hours one day a week. If not, who could stay with her? Finding time for yourself is critical for your sanity and, probably for hers as well. Make the effort.

After you have your respite plan set up, it’s time to make sure she is getting the medical care she needs.

  1. It’s important to find a pain specialist to work with — preferably not your primary care doctor! This level and kind of pain needs to be treated by someone trained to treat it. Pain specialists have a reputation of treating patients like they’re drug addicts looking for a fix. This happened to me and it was humiliating and devastating. Keep looking until you find a doctor who treats you with the professionalism and respect you deserve. You and your pain specialist should work together, as a team, to make decisions on how to treat your pain.
  2. People living in chronic pain also live with depression whether or not that person wants to admit it. People who have been put in the role of caregiver often live with depression, as well. If you are depressed — or suspect you might be — you need to seek medical help to treat your depression. Some people still frown on taking anti-depressants. Ignore them. Depression plays a huge role in the negativity, anger, and irrational behavior of the person living with pain and the frustration of the caregiver.
     
    Depression is the result of a chemical imbalance in your brain. It is a medical problem. You can’t overcome it by willpower, prayer or ignoring it. Depression is not anyone’s fault! If you were diagnosed with diabetes, no one would have a problem with you taking insulin. Depression is similar in that it needs medical treatment. If you need a referral to see a psychiatrist, ask your primary care, but I would not advise anyone to use their PC to treat depression. Depression and anti-depressant medications are a complex situation. Keep this in mind: There are so many antidepressants and you have to increase your dosage slowly so it may take weeks or even months to finally find the right answer for you. Hang in there until it gets better, because it will.
  3. Both of you might want to get some kind of professional help to understand how and why your mood changes so rapidly. The person living with pain needs to learn how to express their feelings without taking their anger and frustration out on the people around them, especially those who love them and take care of them. You, as the caregiver, need help to come to terms with, and accept, that your life is not going to be what you planned, expected or wished it to be. That doesn’t mean you have to give up everything you enjoy, it means you have to learn how to build a different, enjoyable, happy life. At the same time, both of you should decide if you could benefit from a few sessions of couples counseling.
     
    None of this is easy. All of it will require each of you to recommit to your relationship and agree to work it out together. It is going to take time, probably a lot of time. Whatever happened to cause this person to live with chronic pain has undeniably changed your relationship, but that doesn’t have to mean that your happy life is over. You just need to work together to create a new kind of happy life. I wish you the very best of what life offers.

How Can Caretakers Take Care of Themselves?

Susan L Stewart
Apr 1

Living with someone with a chronic illness(es) does not have to be the end of your happiness.

A caregiver asked me once how he should take care of his wife, who is in chronic pain, while still maintaining his own life. If only there were an easy answer!

I have lived with severe chronic pain and overwhelming fatigue for the last 30 years due to fibromyalgia. The pain is so bad I am forced to take serious narcotics just to be able to function. On an occasional good day, I can actually enjoy life and appreciate all that I am blessed with. These days are few and I make sure I appreciate every hour of every one.

I’m going to make some assumptions for the sake of the discussion.

  • Your wife can’t do the things she used to do or wants to do, and you are tired, emotionally and physically.
  • She is sick and unhappy, and you don’t know if you can do this another day.
  • Every day seems like more of the same because nothing gets better. No matter what you do, which doctor she sees or treatment she tries, you are powerless to make any kind of permanent change.

I asked my husband (my caregiver) your question and this is what he said: “You have to try to not be selfish. You have to change the way you look at your life, your outlook on life, and realize you are a caregiver. You have to come to an understanding that you aren’t going to get to do everything you might want to do but you still need time for yourself and time to do things you enjoy. If it gets to a point where she wants you to stay with her all the time and never leave her, it may be time to share your responsibilities with another family member. At some point you may need some outside help so you can get some relief and time away. And, I never forget my wedding vows, made 45 years ago, to love my wife through sickness and in health.”

I have to say my husband is amazing. I have been at a point of being able to do very little for more than ten years. My husband does the grocery shopping, and laundry; he cooks, cleans and holds my hand when it gets really bad. But keep in mind that he has had a lot of years of practice in this caretaker role. He wasn’t always quite as willing to help. It has taken time for him to understand how I feel and what makes it better or worse. It has taken time for me to learn how to help in my small way and what to say to make sure he knows I appreciate him.
 
It’s difficult to describe what it’s like to live with chronic pain, but I’ll try. Pain messes with your mind, thoughts, behavior and patience. It makes it hard to remember things, to enjoy simple things and to be appreciative. It can eat away at your soul if you let it, and make you jealous and bitter, especially about people who seem to walk through life without a care.
 
I had to make a decision more than 20 years ago that I was not going to take my pain, depression and all the other negative feelings out on my husband. I love him, and because I do, I made a commitment to do everything I can to make this as easy on him as possible. I say, “thank you,” and “I’m sorry for . . .” and “I love you” and “I really appreciate everything you do” a lot. I do whatever I can, even if it’s a small thing like putting my cereal bowl and spoon in the dishwasher. If I see a basket of clean towels, I fold them. It’s the thought that counts.

Working out a new life

So what do you do? How do you create a happy life? There are two of you in this relationship and it’s going to take effort from each of you to improve it.

First of all, it is necessary for the caretaker, and the person he takes care of, to come up with a list of things he really doesn’t want to give up. Let’s assume the caretaker is a man and loves to play golf. So, once a week he needs five hours to play golf. Maybe when it’s too cold for golf, he and his buddies go bowling. Whatever. Just think how good it would be to get away from the pressure, and spend some time on the quiet golf course, get some exercise and breathe some fresh air.

Then he has to decide if his wife can be alone for five hours one day a week. If not, who could stay with her? Finding time for yourself is critical for your sanity and, probably for hers as well. Make the effort.

After you have your respite plan set up, it’s time to make sure she is getting the medical care she needs.

  1. It’s important to find a pain specialist to work with — preferably not your primary care doctor! This level and kind of pain needs to be treated by someone trained to treat it. Pain specialists have a reputation of treating patients like they’re drug addicts looking for a fix. This happened to me and it was humiliating and devastating. Keep looking until you find a doctor who treats you with the professionalism and respect you deserve. You and your pain specialist should work together, as a team, to make decisions on how to treat your pain.
  2. People living in chronic pain also live with depression whether or not that person wants to admit it. People who have been put in the role of caregiver often live with depression, as well. If you are depressed — or suspect you might be — you need to seek medical help to treat your depression. Some people still frown on taking anti-depressants. Ignore them. Depression plays a huge role in the negativity, anger, and irrational behavior of the person living with pain and the frustration of the caregiver.
     
    Depression is the result of a chemical imbalance in your brain. It is a medical problem. You can’t overcome it by willpower, prayer or ignoring it. Depression is not anyone’s fault! If you were diagnosed with diabetes, no one would have a problem with you taking insulin. Depression is similar in that it needs medical treatment. If you need a referral to see a psychiatrist, ask your primary care, but I would not advise anyone to use their PC to treat depression. Depression and anti-depressant medications are a complex situation. Keep this in mind: There are so many antidepressants and you have to increase your dosage slowly so it may take weeks or even months to finally find the right answer for you. Hang in there until it gets better, because it will.
  3. Both of you might want to get some kind of professional help to understand how and why your mood changes so rapidly. The person living with pain needs to learn how to express their feelings without taking their anger and frustration out on the people around them, especially those who love them and take care of them. You, as the caregiver, need help to come to terms with, and accept, that your life is not going to be what you planned, expected or wished it to be. That doesn’t mean you have to give up everything you enjoy, it means you have to learn how to build a different, enjoyable, happy life. At the same time, both of you should decide if you could benefit from a few sessions of couples counseling.
     
    None of this is easy. All of it will require each of you to recommit to your relationship and agree to work it out together. It is going to take time, probably a lot of time. Whatever happened to cause this person to live with chronic pain has undeniably changed your relationship, but that doesn’t have to mean that your happy life is over. You just need to work together to create a new kind of happy life. I wish you the very best of what life offers.

Susan L Stewart is an author and editor having walked the long road of writing for more than 20 years. She lives with fibromyalgia and chronic depression and is a mental health advocate. She and husband of 45 years live in a suburb of Denver Colorado.

There is no health without mental health!
